awd_titl_txt: Analysis of the Ribonucleases of Arabidopsis thaliana
awd_abstract_narration:
Changes in gene expression are crucial for plant growth, development and resistance to pathogens.  A better understanding of how gene expression is regulated is fundamental to the process of plant engineering and hence to improved agricultural production.  Plants regulate gene expression at multiple levels and the aim of this project is to characterize proteins called endoribonucleases, which regulate gene expression at the level of mRNA degradation.  An important aspect of this project is to determine how these endoribonucleases impact the biology of plants, including plant growth and development.  This project will train young scientists on fundamental aspects of gene regulation.  The young scientist will receive interdisciplinary training through interactions with collaborators who are experts in systems biology and chemical engineering.  A Shadow a Scientist program will give middle school students the chance to meet scientists, tour a research laboratory, and to see experiments for this project in progress.  Other outreach activities aim to engage the public and to inspire scientific interest in people from a broad range of backgrounds and age groups.  

The long-term goal of this project is to elucidate the roles of ribonucleases (RNases) that participate in mRNA degradation in Arabidopsis.  Examining the roles of endoribonucleases in post-transcriptional control of genes is an underdeveloped area of research, but a timely one.  The hypothesis underlying this proposed research is that elucidating the targets and post-transcriptional impact of endoribonucleases will enhance our understanding of key players in plant mRNA decay, such as the exosome, as well as lesser known or putative endoribonucleases whose role is yet to be discovered.  To test this idea and others, the project will first create a set of double mutants to stabilize mRNA decay intermediates produced by endoribonucleases so they can be deeply sequenced; single endoribonuclease mutations will be introduced into an xrn4 null mutant background to achieve this.  Second, to identify substrates of the endoribonucleases, RNA decay intermediates and RNA levels will be analyzed on a global scale in the double mutants and controls using Parallel Analysis of RNA Ends and RNA-Seq data.  Should any of the endoribonucleases act on nonsense-mediated mRNA decay (NMD) targets, that would be intriguing given that plants lack the metazoan NMD endoribonuclease, SMG6.  Third, new biological impacts of the endoribonucleases will be hypothesized and tested in the single mutants on the basis of the functional associations of their cleaved substrates.  Fourth, post-transcriptional mechanisms that involve the endoribonucleases will be investigated. Localization of the endoribonucleases, the identification of proteins interacting with them and other post-transcriptional data will refine phenotypic hypotheses and models.  Beyond making use of The Virtual Plant for this pursuit, this project will enhance its power with new post-transcriptional components.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This project aimed to enhance understanding of the targets of ribonucleases to better elucidate how these RNA-degrading enzymes contribute to post-transcriptional control mechanisms and biological impacts. Three research articles resulted from the project, including Nagarajan et al., Plant Cell In press (Open Access). All three studies used RNA degradome analysis to identify RNAs that were targeted for decay by ribonucleases studied under the project. The work contributed to Nagarajan et. al., 2019 that identified mRNA decay targets of the plant exoribonuclease XRN4, which degrades RNA from 5' monophosphorylated (5'P) ends. The identity and roles of these XRN4 targets led to new hypotheses and the discovery of new biological impacts of XRN4 during the response to darkness or the response to nitrogen resupply after starvation. The project also contributed to a collaborative study (Hurtig et. al., 2021) of the yeast endoribonuclease TSEN/SEN2. Nagarajan et. al., Plant Cell In press focuses on Arabidopsis DNE1, the plant endoribonuclease that is most closely related to the mammalian endoribonuclease MARF1, which cleaves RNA targets via an NYN domain. More than 200 mRNAs were identified as DNE1 cleavage targets under this investigation. Further, a point mutation known to inactivate the catalytic domain was sufficient to block cleavage of individual substrates in plants. DNE1 is the first MARF1 family member for which endogenous cleavage targets have been identified. The work should provide clues to identify new biological impacts of DNE1 in Arabidopsis. Analysis of the findings also led to a model by which DNE1 acts to control the degradation of its target mRNAs. After being published as an Advance Article in The Plant Cell, Nagarajan et. al. In press, also is slated for inclusion in the upcoming RNA focus issue of The Plant Cell.

 

Broad Impacts

The project supported the training of one graduate student and one honors thesis undergraduate, one associate scientist, and one undergraduate lab assistant. The project also fostered the development of the graduate and undergraduate students' bioinformatics skills through short courses and the analysis of their own transcriptomic data. The computational and bioinformatics skills of the associate scientist have greatly advanced under the project and he has gained valuable mentoring experience guiding the students in these areas and in the laboratory. The associate scientist is now a scientist in major plant biotechnology company. The graduate student completed her M.S. and is now a research assistant in a leading lab studying mRNA decay in yeast. The honors thesis undergraduate is now a Ph.D. student as indicated below.

Project personnel participated in our outreach exhibit, "The Amazing Horseshoe Crab," during Coast Day at the University of Delaware's Lewes Campus in October 2018 and 2019. Although the event was canceled, or the format was not compatible with our exhibit in subsequent years, we plan to pass the materials on to another research group that would like to continue it in the future. The project also supported the development and execution of a Shadow the Scientist program for each of three Middle School honors 7th-grade science classes that were focusing on Life Science. The program was developed and executed via Zoom in 2021. In the survey administered after the program, the majority of the 7th grade students indicated that the Shadow the Scientist program helped them understand science better. Nearly half indicated that the program increased their interest in science. The program also enhanced the commitment of the former undergraduate on the project, to participate in the Shadow a Scientist program that is ongoing at University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, where she is a Ph.D. student.
